title-group.article-title: Detection of delamination in composite laminated plates using filtered mode shapes

article-meta.aff: Department of Aerospace Engineering, Sharif University of Technology, Tehran, Iran

author-notes.corresp: Mohammad Ali Kouchakzadeh, Department of Aerospace Engineering, Sharif University of Technology, Azadi Avenue, PO Box 11155-8639, Tehran, Iran. Email: mak@sharif.edu

abstract.p: Filtered mode shapes are used to detect the presence, location, size and shape of the delaminations in composite laminated plates with various boundary conditions. This method is the extension of a previous study by the authors on the delamination detection in the beams using irregularities of the mode shapes. The mode shapes are filtered to separate the smooth and irregular parts. Presence and situation of delamination affects these separated parts, and these effects are used to detect the delamination. Here, two new indicators, named ‘slope of smooth part’ and ‘irregularities in the slope of smooth part’, are introduced to increase the clarity of detected damage and reduce the noisy effects. The former one is obtained by differentiating the smooth part of the mode shape and the latter by applying the filter on the slope of smooth part for another time. Using this method and the mentioned indicators, delaminations may be detected in the plates using the data of just the damaged structure. This is considered as an important advantage of the method as we do not need the intact structure data. The method is validated utilizing the numerical data for a delaminated plate model. This method lacks the ability to locate the position of delamination through the thickness and the delamination should not be too close to the edges of the plate.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Delamination is one of the most important kinds of damages in composite laminates. The strength of a delaminated structure may reduce considerably, without any visible symptoms. Detection of damages at initial stages can provide higher levels of safety and improve economic operation of the structures.

Many methods for damage detection in various structural members, made of isotropic or composite materials, are considered in literature. Many of these methods are based on a comparison of some indicators of intact and damaged members. The intact member indices are not always available or can be difficult to collect and store.

Hitherto, various geometries were studied. For damage detection in the beams, many methods1–4 are introduced. Some methods, such as Çam et al.,3 need the intact beam data, while some methods, such as Wang and Qiao,4 only need the damaged beam. Wang and Qiao4 applied some filter on the mode shapes of the cracked beams to extract their irregularities, indicating the damage in the structure.

Like beams, damage detection in plates is widely studied in literature.5–9 For example, Yam et al.5 used static method and formulated damage indices in plate-like structures using the out-of-plane deflection, and its slope and curvature based on a finite element model (FEM). Li et al.6 utilized strain modal approach to identify the damage location for plate-like structures.

Besides the beams and plates, other kind of geometry was considered in studies. For example, Ip and Tse10 tried to locate the damage in circular cylindrical composite shells. Liu et al.11 considered the crack detection in hollow section structures, and a planar truss was studied by Wang et al.12

The method of this study is based on modal analysis. It is a well-known dynamic method for damage detection. Any damage usually reduces the stiffness and increases the damping of the system. These changes can alter modal properties of the structure such as mode shape, mode shape curvature or its slope. These indications can be utilized to detect the damage conditions.

The natural frequency is one of the modal parameters used in many articles to identify damage situation.13 This index has some benefits. It is simple to measure the natural frequency, employing a single sensor. In addition, there is a considerable physical relationship between natural frequency and change in mass and stiffness.14 However, the sensitivity of the natural frequency to the damage level is very low, and the change in natural frequency even in critical levels of the failure may not be considerable. Experimental and numerical results of Chen et al.15 indicate that there is less than 10% change in natural frequencies at critical damage state.

Variations of mode shapes or their derivatives are the other widely considered modal parameters to detect damages. Alnefaie,16 by considering the results of numerical simulation, concluded that delamination effect is more clear on mode shapes than it is on frequencies. Furthermore, in the study of Abdo and Hori,17 it was discovered that the rotation of mode shape is a sensitive indicator of damage. In the study of Hu et al.,18 the strain energies of laminated plates were calculated via utilizing mode shapes, before and after a damage was used to define a damage index. Some other researchers8,19,20 utilized curvature of the mode shapes for damage detection.

In this study, we extend the work explained by Kazemi Bazardehi and Kouchakzade21 for delamination detection in beams to laminated plates. In this method, utilizing a filter, the irregularities of the mode shapes are extracted and these irregularities are used to detect the damage situation. In addition, two new indicators, named ‘slope of smooth part (SSP)’ and ‘irregularities in the slope of smooth part (ISSP)’, are introduced to determine the delamination situation in a composite laminated plate more clearly. The most important advantage of this method is that unlike some other methods, in many cases, the exact mode shapes of the intact plate are not required and the mode shapes of the damaged plate are sufficient.

sec.title: Delamination detection utilizing irregularity of mode shape
sec.p: As explained in Wang and Qiao4 and Kazemi Bazardehi and Kouchakzade,21 damage in a structure results in irregularity in the mode shapes of the structure. This irregularity usually has a very small effect and cannot be detected in the mode shape. To diagnose this irregularity, it should be uncovered and amplified. In this method, modal analysis is primarily used and mode shapes of the beam are obtained; subsequently, the mode shapes are filtered and their irregularities are extracted.

sec.title: Extracting mode shapes of a delaminated plate
sec.p: In this method, modal analysis is the first step for detection of delamination in a plate. Different methods can be utilized to obtain the mode shapes of a delaminated plate. Here, the numerical method is used. In applications, the mode shapes data can be obtained from the test of the possibly damaged beam, e.g. applying scanning laser vibrometer.

In numerical method, modal analysis is performed on the FEM of the delaminated plate. To make this FEM, the plate is considered as two separate upper and lower parts. The adjacent nodes on these parts are coupled in all directions along the plate except for the delaminated region. Solid elements were used for the finite element analysis and the convergence check is performed to be sure about the validity of the results.

sec.title: Filtering
sec.p: To extract the irregularities from the obtained mode shapes, they should be filtered. As explained in Kazemi Bazardehi and Kouchakzade21 for beams mode shape filtering, the one-dimensional (1-D) filter (Gaussian filter) is utilized (1)f (x)=1αλcexp(-π(xαλc)2)
However, for plates, the following two-dimensional (2-D) filter should be used (2)f (x,y)=1αλcexp(-π((xαλc)2+(yαλc)2))

In this filter, α=ln2/π and λc are the cut-off wavelength which should be determined in such a way that filter will have the maximum power of separation of irregularity from the mode shape. In this study, based on the results of many cases, the value of λc = 0.022 is used.

Hereinafter, smooth parts of a three-dimensional (3-D) function, such as mode shape of a plate (W) and its irregularity, are demonstrated by S(W) and E(W), respectively. S and E operate on each point of the function (here mode shape) according to equations (3) and (4) (3)S(W(x0,y0))=∫-∞ ∞∫-∞ ∞W(x0+x,y0+y) f (x,y) dx dy
(4)E(W(x0,y0))=W(x0,y0)-S(W(x0,y0))

Here, W is the magnitude of mode shape and f the filter function to smooth the mode shape. Using equation (3), the smooth part of mode shape is calculated, and equation (4) extracts the irregularities of the mode shape.

In Figure 1, a clamped delaminated plate is shown. Figure 2 displays the schematic first mode shape of this plate. This mode shape may be the result of experiments or it can be obtained utilizing numerical or analytical methods. Figure 1.
Delamination area in a clamped plate.
Figure 2.
Schematic first mode shape of the plate.

As can be seen in Figure 2, despite the presence of the delamination in the plate, no effect of delamination is observed in the mode shape. The weak effect of the delamination on the mode shape should be separated and amplified using a filter. To achieve this, smooth part of the mode shape (S(W)) is primarily extracted (Figure 3); afterwards by subtracting the curve of smoothed mode shape (Figure 3) from the original mode shape (Figure 2), the irregularity of the mode shape (E(W)) can be extracted, as shown in Figure 4. The delamination effect is now clearly visible in Figure 4. Figure 3.
Smooth part of the mode shape.
Figure 4.
Irregularity of the mode shape.

In some cases, for example, a plate with free-boundary conditions, some noisy effects may be seen in the profile of the E(W). Figure 5 shows some kind of noisy effect in addition to the main part of the profile (original mode shape) and the irregularity resulted from the presence of damage. Figure 5.
Noisy effects in the irregularity of the mode shape (second mode of a free plate).

This study shows that, to reduce the noisy effect, instead of irregularity of the mode shape (E), we can use the SSP, S∧ , of the mode shape as a new indicator, defined by equation (5) (5)S∧(x,y)=(∂∂x+∂∂y)S(x,y)

In Figure 6, the SSP of the second mode shape is shown. The noisy effect is reduced in the S∧ and only the main parts (similar to mode shape), together with the damage effect, are visible. Figure 6.
SSP profile of the mode shape. SSP: slope of smooth part.

As it is demonstrated in the Figures 4 and 6, the irregularity resulted from the presence of damage is mounted on the main part of the profile. To improve the clarity and achieve the pure effect of the damage, the filter can be used once more, employing another indicator we call ‘ISSP’. This index is the irregular part of the SSP ( E(S∧(W)) ). Figure 7 shows the profile of this indicator, which is calculated by twice applying of the filter on Figure 2. As it is shown, the damage situation is clearly visible. Figure 7.
ISSP of the mode shape demonstrated in Figure 2. ISSP: irregularities in the slope of smooth part.

Filtered values at every point are related to the value of the mode shape at that point and nearby points. Close to the edges of the plate, calculation of the filtered values may encounter problems as no value can be attributed to the mode shape for some of the nearby points. This imposes a limitation on the method, and it should be assumed that there is not any delamination in the vicinity of the edges. The percentage of the lost information is related to the value of λc. Decreasing λc reduces the lost information; however, it affects the quality of the filter and we need to make a balance. Here, λc = 0.022 is used, and the lost percentage is around 7% of the plate width from each edge.

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p:
Different cases of plates with known delamination situations are considered and the results of this study are presented to validate and show the ability of the method to determine the delamination situation. For this purpose, a plate with a [0/90]s stacking sequence is considered (Figure 8). The dimensions of the four-ply plate are 400 × 400 × 4 mm3 and the material properties of the lamina are presented in Table 1. Various sizes and locations of delamination (along the length and thickness), multiple delamination and different boundary conditions are investigated. The mode shapes are obtained utilizing numerical simulation (FEM) and only the mode shapes of the plate in the thickness direction are considered. Considering the convergence check, the 3-D FEM for each layer is made of 80 × 80 eight-node solid elements of equal size. Figure 8.

sec.title: Delamination location, size and shape
sec.p:
To study the ability of the current method to determine the location (on the surface), size and shape of the delamination, three different cases (A, B and C as demonstrated in Figure 9) are considered. The delaminations are located at interface 2 and all edges of the plate have clamped boundary conditions. SSP and ISSP of the mode shapes are extracted. Figures 10 to 12 shows the results for three cases: A, B and C. It can be observed that the situation of delaminations can be determined using irregularity profiles. Figure 10.
Case A: (a) SSP of the first mode shape; (b) ISSP of the first mode shape; (c) SSP of the second mode shape; and (d) ISSP of the second mode shape. SSP: slope of smooth part; ISSP: irregularities in the slope of smooth part.
Figure 12.
Case C: (a) SSP of the first mode shape; (b) ISSP of the first mode shape; (c) SSP of the second mode shape; and (d) ISSP of the second mode shape. SSP: slope of smooth part; ISSP: irregularities in the slope of smooth part.
Figure 9.
Three different location cases of delamination region.

To study the ability of the method to detect delamination location through the thickness of the plate, a plate similar to case A with delamination at interface 1 is considered (Figure 8). Figure 13 displays the SSP and ISSP of the first mode. By comparing Figures 13 and 10(a) and (b), it can be observed that irregularity profiles are not considerably sensitive to the location of delamination through the thickness and this method cannot determine delamination location through the thickness. Figure 11.
Case B: (a) SSP of the first mode shape; (b) ISSP of the first mode shape; (c) SSP of the second mode shape; and (d) ISSP of the second mode shape. SSP: slope of smooth part; ISSP: irregularities in the slope of smooth part.
Figure 13.
Delamination at interface 1 (case A): (a) SSP of the first mode shape and (b) ISSP of the first mode shape. SSP: slope of smooth part; ISSP: irregularities in the slope of smooth part.
Figure 14.
Multiple delaminations in the plate (at interface 2).

To study the minimum dimensions of the delamination that can be detected with this method, some different sizes of delaminations are considered. According to the results, using SSP and ISSP indicators, we can detect delaminations even smaller than one thousandth of area of the plate.

sec.title: Multiple delamination
sec.p:
There can be more than one delamination in a plate. The SSP and ISSP extracted from numerical mode shape, for a clamped plate with two delaminations, as shown in Figure 14, is demonstrated in Figure 15. Again, it can be seen that the presence, location and situation of delaminations can be distinctly detected, providing that they are not too close to each other. Figure 15.
Multiple delaminations: (a) SSP of the first mode shape and (b) ISSP of the first mode shape. SSP: slope of smooth part; ISSP: irregularities in the slope of smooth part.

sec.title: Other boundary conditions
sec.p:
In the preceding sections, we considered clamped plates. Now, some other boundary conditions are considered. Figures 16 and 17 show the SSP and ISSP of the two mode shapes for free and simply supported delaminated plates, respectively. In all cases, the delamination is as case B in Figure 9, placed at interface 2. In free-boundary conditions, the rigid body mode shapes are disregarded and the first mode shape, due to its inappropriate result, is not considered. Figure 16.
Free plate: (a) SSP of the second mode shape; (b) ISSP of the second mode shape; (c) SSP of the third mode shape; (d) ISSP of the third mode shape. SSP: slope of smooth part; ISSP: irregularities in the slope of smooth part.
Figure 17.
Simply supported plate: (a) SSP of the first mode shape; (b) ISSP of the first mode shape; (c) SSP of the second mode shape; and (d) ISSP of the second mode shape. SSP: slope of smooth part; ISSP: irregularities in the slope of smooth part.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Here, the method formerly introduced by Wang and Qiao4 for crack detection and utilized to determine the delamination situation in a beam by Kazemi Bazardehi and Kouchakzade21 is extended for delamination detection in plates. In addition, two new indicators, named ‘SSP’ and ‘ISSP’, are introduced to increase the clarity of detection.

In this method, the mode shapes of the plate are filtered to separate the smooth and the irregularity parts. Presence of any delamination and its situation, affects the extracted parts, is utilized for delamination detection. While many other damage detection methods require the mode shapes of the intact structure to detect its damages, the current method in many cases needs just the data of the damaged structure. This is considered as an important advantage of the current method.

To clarify the damage more precisely and reduce the noisy effects on the results, ‘SSP’, calculated by differentiating the smooth part of the mode shape, was used as a new indicator. In addition, to improve the clarity and achieve the pure effect of the damage, we can use the filter once more and employ another new indicator called ‘ISSP’.

The method was validated utilizing the numerical data for a delaminated plate model. In many cases, by considering three first mode shapes, the method can be applied to obtain a reasonable approximation on the presence of delamination, its location, its size and its shape, in composite laminated plates with various boundary conditions. This method lacks the ability to detect the position of delamination through the thickness and the delamination should not be too close to the edges of the plate.
